claim: People in England spend more time working now than in the past.

supporting.text: Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have increased since 2000.

attacks.text: Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have increased since 2000.
The increase in average working hours may be skewed by part-time workers shifting to full-time employment, not necessarily longer hours for the same workers.
Even if part-time to full-time shifts contribute, official statistics often adjust for such changes to reflect true working-hour trends.
The rise in gig economy jobs, often underreported in official statistics, may mask a decline in traditional full-time working hours.
Recent improvements in labor data collection now better capture gig economy work, making the statistics more reliable.

supporting.text: Technological advancements have blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, leading to more hours spent on work-related activities.

attacks.text: Technological advancements have blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, leading to more hours spent on work-related activities.
Work-from-home policies and flexible hours have actually reduced total working hours by eliminating commutes and allowing better time management.
Studies show that remote workers often work longer hours due to difficulty disconnecting from work tasks.
Labor laws and union agreements in England strictly regulate working hours, preventing significant increases.
Many workers are now classified as self-employed or gig workers, bypassing traditional labor protections.

supporting.text: The rise of the gig economy and flexible working arrangements has resulted in people taking on multiple jobs or working longer hours.

attacks.text: The rise of the gig economy and flexible working arrangements has resulted in people taking on multiple jobs or working longer hours.
Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in England have remained stable or slightly decreased over the past decade.
The gig economy represents a small fraction of the workforce, and its impact on overall working hours is marginal compared to traditional employment.
Many gig economy workers report underemployment and struggle to secure full-time hours, leading to lower total working time than traditional jobs.
Studies indicate that gig workers often supplement their income with multiple part-time roles, cumulatively exceeding standard full-time hours.

supporting.text: Economic pressures, such as inflation and stagnant wages, have compelled many to work longer hours to maintain their standard of living.

attacks.text: Economic pressures, such as inflation and stagnant wages, have compelled many to work longer hours to maintain their standard of living.
Technological advancements and remote work have increased productivity, allowing people to work fewer hours while maintaining or even improving their standard of living.
Despite increased productivity, the benefits have not been evenly distributed, and many workers still face economic pressures that require longer hours.
Government policies and labor laws in England have reduced maximum working hours, making it harder for people to work longer than in the past.
While labor laws exist, enforcement is inconsistent, and many workers, especially in gig economy jobs, still work longer hours than legally permitted.

supporting.text: Remote work has eliminated commuting time for many, but studies indicate this saved time is often reallocated to additional work tasks.

attacks.text: Remote work has eliminated commuting time for many, but studies indicate this saved time is often reallocated to additional work tasks.
Many remote workers use saved commuting time for personal activities, leisure, or family, not additional work.
Surveys show that remote workers often struggle with work-life balance, leading to longer work hours despite saved commuting time.
Not all jobs can be performed remotely, so the impact of remote work on overall working hours in England is limited.
Even for non-remote jobs, automation and digital tools have increased productivity, potentially reducing the need for longer hours.

supporting.text: Historical data indicates that the average workweek in England was shorter in the mid-20th century compared to the present day.

attacks.text: Historical data indicates that the average workweek in England was shorter in the mid-20th century compared to the present day.
The comparison ignores the rise of part-time work and flexible schedules, which may reduce the average workweek for many individuals.
Even with part-time work, full-time employment data still shows an increase in average weekly hours compared to the mid-20th century.
Historical data may not account for unpaid labor (e.g., domestic work), which was more prevalent in the mid-20th century, skewing comparisons.
Modern studies adjust for unpaid labor and still find an increase in paid working hours, supporting the original claim.
